posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: hey, REV Vortex users (and @Greg_Needel ) do you-all have any sort of guide to making shaft supports for the neo vortex cantilever?  we’re using the integrated pinion (which i think is great), and the plan is to turn down the end of it to 8mm, to fit a 608.  does that seem like a good thing to do?

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
We used the 7 tooth pinion shafts for Vortex motors this year on our elevator gearbox in order to get a 12:1 reduction out of a single stage .

We did not support the far end of the shafts and had no issues, but I don’t see any problem with your plan to use an 8mm bearing either - as long as your lathe can cut the (hardened ?) steel gear teeth.

image 1203×906 112 KB

image 1203×906 112 KB

image 1203×906 112 KB

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: oh, interesting.  so maybe the shaft cantilever isn’t always an issue?  i’m not sure what the failure mechanism actually is.

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked:
If you want additional support this portion of the gear is 13.75mm for standard FRC bearing. image 442×842 22.2 KB

image 442×842 22.2 KB

image 442×842 22.2 KB

We also now sell a 1" OD 13.75mm ID bearing for some alternative packaging opportunities. REV-21-3197 image 960×960 58 KB

image 960×960 58 KB

image 960×960 58 KB

Another option could be to use our new REV-21-3199 bearing sized for #10 screws: image 960×960 52.2 KB This would enable you to use the 10-32 tapped hole on the end of the gear and have the screw serve as the axle for the end support.

image 960×960 52.2 KB

image 960×960 52.2 KB

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 4.5

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
Ok, thanks.

Note i don’t really want additional support, I’m really wondering if i need additional support.  I imagine you-all have done some analysis of the failures that have been reported, so, what did you learn?  What should I know?

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked: We have not seen any failures from cantilevering REV-21-6800.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: oh!  i won’t worry about it then.  thanks!
We managed to shear the face plate on the vortex once due to cantilever mounting, though that was specifically the 8mm shaft on an mk4i drive.
